div1.p: [Carter] discusses malaria infections missed by careful blood examination.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Kenneth F. Maxcy, January 28, 1923
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
2121 California St.
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington D. C
Jan 28/23
Dear Dr Maxcy:
div1.p:
I am not purposing to bother you with any new problems,
nor indeed have I time to set them forth to you, & yet since
you are interested with “Indices of Mal. Infec'n” here is a piece
of datum which sh'd interest you & which you might keep
in mind in case it may help to explain something that
comes up.

1) In the latter part of Nov. 1914, von Ezdorf intook 1660 - thick
films, at Scott Miss: Mayne - then Mitzmain - from the
same community took 1184. The first gave 41.11% +;
the second 39.9% +; practically the same figure. Both same
men competent & the number examined large enough to exclude accidental errors.

Von E. considered that his index was taken after the close
of the malaria season- i.e. that there would be no new in-
fections there after. Of this I am not sure; hibernation is
intermittent in this section & mosquitoes infective
when cold weather came on might well infect
w if they fed during warm days in December.
Wenyon has shown that a short hibernation- a matter
of days or it may be of a couple of weeks - does not (in the
(About Salonica) Ialways sterilize Anopheles. I judge however,
from what I know of von E., that his statement was so
near
2. Maxcy.
near right that we can say - very few were infected after
his index. Let us disregard them, as negligible.

Mayne's is belief that in his index were none who were not infec-
ted by the spring brood-whether of hibernated females.in the previous winter
or the newly developed ones- is I think, absolutely true.
He found no inf Anopheles infected- out of 1211 dissected
up to May 14 where the 1st infected one found May 15. This finding is a amply confirmed by simi-
lar observations by Mayne, later at Talladega springs &
(I think) at Monroe La: & by King & Von Dine at Mound La
Anopheles in that section do not carry the parasite over
the winter

Now these indices being practically the same, it is evident
(1) that approximately all the men who were + in Nov. were
+ in Feb. & that all who were - in Nov: were - in Feb.
or (2) that about the same number who changed from
+ to - in the interval made the contrary change
from - to +.

Now among those examined by M. there was a record
of 103 found + by von E., Of these M. found 48 + &
55 - (47% & 53% respectively) This number, 103 is too small to justify us in
considering it as representative of the community.
If we did it was it would imply that approximatly
50% (53% really) of those not found + in the fall w became so in the spring!
Allowing for new comers & some infections after V. E. Index, if w'd
show a very large percentage of infections, not patent to a
careful blood exam'n by competent men
in the fall
3
Men in the fall of 1914.

Of course we have long known that all mal. infections
were not discoverable by blood examinations. This
was well shown by same of Geiger's work at Lanoke during the winter of 1918 & in
deed on this belief depends the use of the provaca-
tive intra-venous injection of various foreign proteids
I do not think however that it was held that a large
% age escaped discovery. Koch's Stephansort, steriliza-
tion of carried was based on the doctrine - which
Koch affirmed - that if parasites were not found on a
careful examination of the blood, the man was free
from infection. The same, I think (am not so positive of this)
was the contention of Bass in his Bolivar Co. Campaign
in 1916. I think that he only gave quinine to those
whose bloods he found +. (Later, in Sunflower Co. he
gave quinine to these and also to all others who had
had malaria the previous year).

It is then this considerable, or large, % age of infections
missed by even a careful blood examination -thick
films- & in the hands of careful men which I would
bring to your attention. It may be well to bear
it in mind

I attempted to get other data on this subject- i.e. the
spontaneous change from patent to latent & vi in-
fection of the blood & vice versa; but secured none
